This week, Colombian guerrillas freed two women they had held in a jungle camp the better part of a decade.

Clara Rojas and Consuelo Gonzales are enjoying their new found freedom since Venezuelan President Hugo Chaves brokered a deal with their captors, the FARC guerrilla organization.

Gonzales, a former congresswoman, abducted in 2001, spoke of hearing how her husband died during her captivity.

I imagine how you feel.

Rojas, a politician kidnapped in 2002, recalled how she and the guerrilla commander conceived a baby boy, and how she gave birth in a jungle camp.

Living in the jungle meant rice and beans every day, unless the rebels were able to hunt wild game.
